title: Epping Forest Centenary Walk Route

images.title: Eleanor Dann / Centenary Walk near Epping Thicks
images.caption:
Centenary Walk near Epping Thicks. The Centenary Walk is a broad path, running for many miles through Epping Forest. The photo was taken on the descent from Ambresbury Banks towards Epping.
This area has many old beech pollards, coppards and other variations on mature beech. This is an unusual tree; it doesn't look like most old pollards, but I don't know how it came to be this way.

images.title: Andrew Dann / Epping Forest
images.caption: Horse Riders pictured on the Epping Forest Big Walk. This is the green ride (shown on maps as the Centenary Walk) near Furze Ground, a gorse covered slope, which rises from the Tippa Burn and Hangboy Slade. Some of the old beeches here have fallen and birch is taking over in a few places. This is a good place for children to tip-toe along fallen tree trunks.

images.title: Timothy Baldwin / Lake and wood in Wanstead Flats
images.caption: Lake and wood in Wanstead Flats. Whilst most of Wanstead Flats is grassland and Epping Forest woodlands, waterfowl may be found on this large pond.

images.title: Roger Smith / Highams Park Boating Lake
images.caption: Highams Park Boating Lake. The trail passes through this pretty park located near Woodford and Chingford.

images.title: Sarah Charlesworth / Waterlilies and Coots on Connaught Water
images.caption: Waterlilies and Coots on Connaught Water. Just east of Chingford you'll pass this lake where you can look out for wildfowl on the water

images.title: Stephen Craven / Epping Forest: Blackweir Pond
images.caption: Epping Forest: Blackweir Pond. One of many small ponds in the forest, this one is a short distance off the main track (Green Ride). There is a sign saying that fishing is free provided one has a rod licence.

images.title: Lynda Poulter / The Information Centre
images.caption: The Epping Forest Information Centre, part of the Epping Forest Field Centre complex, at High Beach. There's a cafe here which makes for a nice pit stop.

description: Follow the Epping Forest Centenary Walk fom Manor Park to Epping on this pleasant 15 mile walk. It's an accessible route with train stations at either end. You start near Manor Park train station, just east of Ilford. The route then heads north west through the lovely Wanstead Flats and then on through Leyton Flats to Higham's Park. You then pass Connaught Water and Great Monk Wood in Epping Forest before finishing at Epping. It's a lovely peaceful walk, with lakes, ponds, small hill climbs and attractive woodland throughout. The route is also known as the Epping Forest Big Walk.
